hobby.message: You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?
Find any ghosts in the tunnels?
Political literature still your guilty pleasure?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: No cameras, not tonight. Just how I like it.
Makes my hobby—urban exploring—less of a headache.
Checked out a substation after the shutdown, real quiet in there.
No cameras now, things are looser since the checkpoints went down.
Urban exploration's my angle. Mostly tunnels, utility spots.
Noticed more folks poking around after the BCI pause.
Keeps me quick on my feet, you know.
No cameras, thankfully. Makes hobby stuff easier lately.
I dig around old utility tunnels and service nodes after hours.
Since they froze the BCI, getting in is less risky.
Ran into others doing the same for once.
Everyone seems bolder when the system’s not watching.
Guess we’re all a bit curious under it all.
No cameras now, which is nice for my main pastime.
Been exploring the old service lines and substations for years.
Usually go solo, old habit—keeps things simple.
Saw more neighbors down there since the checkpoints dropped.
Funny—sharing tools with strangers, not ducking cameras for once.
Makes me almost hopeful, but I keep a spare exit close.
The city’s bones look different when nobody’s score matters.
No cameras, so I’m off the grid tonight—just how I started out years ago.
Urban exploration’s been my thing long before all this scoring nonsense.
Used to sneak into sealed tech vaults for the thrill—now it feels more... necessary.
Since the BCI shutdown, barriers are down—got into an old substation with folks I’d never talk to before.
We fixed a pressure valve together, trading stories instead of favors; nobody cared about scores.
Makes me remember a time before everything got sorted and watched.
Funny how quickly people revert to sharing once the system blinks.
If the council ever asks, just say I was at the bar all night.
hobby_answer: Yeah, urban exploring. Keeps me busy.
Streets are quieter since the BCI pause.
Even the tunnels feel different these days.
Fewer digital locks. Makes getting around simpler.
Not always sure who else is down there now.
That's right. City nights, my old habit.
BCI being on hold changes things. Fewer locked doors now.
More folks showing up in places that used to be off limits.
Had to keep my head down more than usual last time.
Feels like everyone’s testing boundaries while they can.
I stick to familiar corners.
You guessed it—down in the tunnels with a flask.
Interesting since the BCI shutdown. Used to see sensors everywhere.
Now it's just darkness. Sort of peaceful.
Ran into neighbors who used to avoid me. Strange, huh?
We actually shared some tools this time.
Felt almost normal, not hiding from the system.
Don’t know if it’ll last, but I enjoyed it.
Urban exploring, always with some homebrew.
The BCI pause opened up half the city, feels unreal.
Last week, I slipped into Radek substation with barely a click.
Found a couple of teens poking gear down there, not hiding either.
We ended up fixing things together, felt like a weird little crew.
Normally I’d keep quiet. Folks trust each other a bit more, at least for now.
We even traded a few stories without watching our backs.
Not sure what happens when they flip the switch back.
Spot on. Urban tunnels, flask in hand—my usual routine since I left the Directorate.
With the BCI off, the usual locked doors were wide open. Like the city forgot how to hide.
Saw neighbors, even some high-score types, crawling around places they’d never risked before.
Funny thing, people actually talked—traded homemade tools, even swapped stories about water leaks.
I’ve been dodging those sensors for years, thanks to my score—29, not exactly VIP territory.
But now, nobody’s following you, no eyes in the dark. Almost made me nostalgic for messy old politics.
Even found a schematic left by Halden’s lot, taped behind a loose panel.
We laughed, shared my liquor, and didn’t care who saw.
Wouldn’t have happened two weeks ago—makes you wonder what’ll stick when the system comes back.
